questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is evaluated for short stature. Examination reveals the following findings. Laboratory results indicate low levels of cortisol and ACTH. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in a transcription factor vital for the development of corticotrophs. Which transcription factor mutation is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Congenital Hypopituitarism

Developmental causes

Pituitary dysplasia (Most Common)

Abnormal development of the pituitary gland, which can be aplastic (absent), hypoplastic (underdeveloped), or ectopic (misplaced).

Transcription factor defects:

Pit-1 (Option D ruled out): Determines cell-specific expression of growth hormone (GH), prolactin (PRL), and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in somatotrophs, lactotrophs, and thyrotrophs respectively.

 

Prop-1 (Option A ruled out): Induces development of somatotropes, lactotrope, thyrotrope and gonadotropes.

 

T-Pit: Development of Corticotrope cells. Cause ACTH deficiency and hypocortisolism

 

HESX1: Septo-optic dysplasia with combined pituitary hormone deficiency

 

LHX3 (Option B ruled out): Combined pituitary hormone deficiency with cervical spine rigidity.

 

PAX6 & SOX2.

Clinical Features

GH deficiency

  • Poor growth and short stature in children (Height below the 3rd percentile for age.)
  • Midline Craniofacial Disorders: Abnormalities in midline structures (like the eyes and corpus callosum) can be associated with pituitary dysplasia due to the developmental pathways shared during embryogenesis.

LH/FSH deficiency

  • Children - delayed puberty/sexual development
  • External genitalia is undeveloped - microphallus, small testes and scrotum
  • Lack of body and facial hair
  • If hypopituitarism occurs post puberty
    • Scrotum, testes and penile length is normal or it may slightly regress
    • Gradual loss of body and facial hair occurs.

ACTH deficiency

  • Hypotension, hypoglycemia, stress intolerance
  • Doll-like facies (plump, rounded face with chubby cheeks and a smooth, pale complexion).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to concerns about his growth and appearance. His height is below the 3rd percentile for his age, and the clinician suspects congenital hypopituitarism. Which syndromes are least likely to be associated with his condition?
questions.explanation:
Syndromes associated with Congenital hypopituitarism:

Kallmann Syndrome (Option A ruled out)

Characterized by the absence of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and often associated with anosmia (loss of smell).

Prader-Willi Syndrome (Option C ruled out)

Involves hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, obesity, and developmental delays due to microdeletions on chromosome 15.

Bardet-Biedl Syndrome (Option B ruled out)

A rare genetic disorder involving obesity, intellectual disability, and renal abnormalities, along with potential GnRH deficiency.

Leptin and Leptin Receptor Mutations

Result in obesity and central hypogonadism due to impaired GnRH production

Septo-optic dysplasia

Congenital disorder involving underdevelopment of the optic nerves and midline brain structures.

It is often associated with hypopituitarism, hypogonadism and HESX1 mutations.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with fatigue, abdominal obesity , dry skin, decreased libido, and irregular menstrual cycles. Laboratory tests reveal low cortisol (3 µg/dL) and low ACTH levels. To confirm ACTH deficiency and to assess growth hormone reserve, which investigation is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Investigation of patients with Pituitary disease

ACTH Deficiency
  • Short ACTH Stimulation Test: Initial test for ACTH function.
  • Insulin Tolerance Test: The gold standard for diagnosing ACTH deficiency, as it effectively assesses both cortisol and growth hormone responses.
    • It can lead to severe hypoglycemia and should be performed under close medical supervision.
    • In situations where hypoglycemia poses a risk, the rapid ACTH stimulation test is often preferred.
    • It is contraindicated in Ischemic heart disease & Epilepsy.

LH/FSH Deficiency
  • Men: Measure random serum testosterone, LH, and FSH.
  • Pre-menopausal Women: Assess menstrual regularity.
  • Post-menopausal Women: Measure random serum LH and FSH (expected FSH > 30 IU/L, LH > 20 IU/L).

TSH Deficiency:

Serum T4 levels; TSH often detectable in secondary hypothyroidism

Growth hormone deficiency
  • Investigate only if considering GH replacement therapy.

Stimulation tests for GH:

  • Insulin-Induced Hypoglycemia
  • Arginine (may combine with GHRH)
  • Glucagon
  • Clonidine (in children)

Among anterior pituitary hormones GH & ACTH requires provocative tests others are assessed by pituitary function tests

Disorders

Diagnostic Tests

Acromegaly

Oral glucose tolerance test

Conn syndrome

Plasma aldosterone to renin ratio (Screening test)

Saline Infusion Test / Salt Loading Test

Addison disease

Morning serum cortisol and ACTH (Screening test)

ACTH stimulation/cosyntropin test

Diabetes insipidus

Water deprivation test

SIADH

Serum and urine osmolality (Screening)

Water loading test

Hypopituitarism

Insulin tolerance test

Cushing's disease

Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test

Pheochromocytoma

Plasma-free metanephrine test

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with enlarged hands, facial changes, and spacing between his lower teeth. Lab results show elevated growth hormone and IGF-1 levels. What is the most common cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Acromegaly

Causes
  • GH-secreting pituitary adenomas (>1cm-macroadenoma) (Most Common)
  • Mixed mammosomatotroph tumors (25%) (Option A ruled out)
  • Acidophilic stem cell adenomas, which also secrete prolactin (PRL), lead to symptoms such as hypogonadism and galactorrhea.
  • Carcinoid tumor: Excess GNRH production (Option D ruled out)
  • Tumors in the pancreas, ovaries, and lungs: Ectopic GH secretion (Option C ruled out)

Clinical features
  • Acral bony overgrowth
    • Frontal bossing
    • Enlarged hands and feet
    • Mandibular enlargement with prognathism
    • Widened spaces between lower incisor teeth.
  • Soft tissue swelling:
    • Increased heel pad thickness (>25mm)
    • Larger shoe and glove sizes
    • Ring tightening
    • Coarse facial features
    • Macroglossia
  • Visceromegaly: particularly cardiomegaly and thyroid enlargement
  • Other symptoms
    • Hyperhidrosis and oily skin
    • Deep voice,
    • Arthropathy, kyphosis and carpal tunnel syndrome,
    • Muscle weakness and atrophy
    • Acanthosis nigricans and skin tags.

Complications
  • Cardiomyopathy: Characterized by arrhythmias, left ventricular hypertrophy, decreased diastolic function, and hypertension.
  • Upper airway obstruction: Sleep apnea, caused by laryngeal obstruction and central sleep dysfunction, affects over 60% of patients.
  • Diabetes mellitus: Approximately 25% of patients develop diabetes, as GH antagonizes insulin action.
  • Hypertension
  • Arthritis
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Colon polyps and malignancy, with up to one-third of patients at risk
  • Mass effect by the adenoma, including visual disturbances.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with symptoms suggestive of acromegaly, including enlarged hands and facial changes. To confirm the diagnosis, which of the following tests is most appropriate to demonstrate the presence of the condition?

A 45-year-old man presents with enlarged hands and feet, visual field defects, facial changes, and headaches. MRI reveals findings as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Management of Acromegaly

Surgical Treatment

Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment, especially for those with GH-secreting adenomas.

 

Post-Surgery:

  • Improvement in soft tissue swelling and normalization of GH levels typically occur shortly after surgery
  • IGF-1 levels normalize within 3-4 days.
  • There is a 10% recurrence rate of acromegaly years later, and up to 15% of patients may develop hypopituitarism.

Medical therapy

Preferred in medical therapy if curative surgery is not feasible or if GH fails to decrease post resection

  • Somatostatin Receptor Ligands (SRLs): (Option B ruled out)
    • Long-acting injectable forms (octreotide, lanreotide).
    • Normalizes GH and IGF-1 levels in about 50% of patients.
    • Side Effects: GI disturbances, transient nausea, and gallbladder issues.
  • GH receptor antagonist:
    • Pegvisomant blocks peripheral GH receptors, normalizing IGF-1 levels in about 70% of patients, though GH levels remain elevated. It is administered through daily subcutaneous injections and is used for recurrences or poor responses to SRLs.
  • Dopamine Agonists: (Option A ruled out)
    • High doses of cabergoline can provide modest GH suppression.

Radiation Therapy (Option D ruled out)

External beam radiation therapy or stereotactic techniques are considered for patients not achieving biochemical control through surgery or medical therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman experiences severe postpartum hemorrhage during delivery, requiring a blood transfusion. Two weeks later, she reports fatigue, weight loss, and inability to breastfeed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Sheehan Syndrome
Pathology

Decrease in anterior pituitary hormones due to ischemic damage of anterior pituitary

Initial Symptoms

Classic early sign is failed lactation following delivery

Varied Symptoms

Based on the severity of pituitary damage

  • Severe Hypopituitarism:
    • Early symptoms :lethargy, anorexia, and weight loss soon after delivery.
    • Delayed Symptoms: Secondary amenorrhea, loss of sexual hair, and fatigue may develop weeks to months later.
 
  • Growth Hormone (GH) deficiency: Often the first hormone to be lost, leading to Hypoglycemia, muscle weakness, and mood swings.
 
  • Signs of Premature aging: Wrinkling of face
 
  • ACTH Deficiency: Can cause postural hypotension & worsen hypoglycemia.
 
  • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) Deficiency: Results in secondary hypothyroidism . Unlike primary hypothyroidism, frank myxoedema is rare.
 
  • Approximately ⅓ rd may present with hyponatremia, while Central diabetes insipidus is rarely observed.

 

Sheehan syndrome

Simmonds disease

Cause

Ischemic damage to the anterior pituitary due to acute infarction

Gradual degeneration or destruction of the pituitary due to hypertension / SCD

Symptoms

Failure to lactate, lethargy, anorexia, and weight loss shortly after delivery

 

Secondary amenorrhea, loss of sexual hair, fatigue, and wrinkling of the face (premature ageing) can occur as delayed symptoms.

Gradual weakness, weight loss, and signs of pituitary hormone deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for a patient with Sheehan syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Sheehan syndrome

Investigations

Brain MRI/CECT

  • A secondary partial or complete empty sella

(Primary empty sella syndrome, or arachnoidocele, is a radiologic finding where the sella turcica appears empty due to CSF herniation from the subarachnoid space, compressing and flattening the pituitary gland within it.).

  • Serum findings
    • Growth hormone, Prolactin, ACTH, TSH, LH and FSH ↓.
    • ADH is normal as the posterior pituitary is typically not affected.

Management

Hormone Replacement Therapies:

  • Cortisol Replacement:
    • Administer hydrocortisone (Initial treatment) if there is ACTH deficiency.
    • Mineralocorticoid is not typically recommended. (Option C)
 
  • Thyroid Hormone Replacement:
    • Indication: Levothyroxine (50–150 μg) should be given once daily.
    • Aim to maintain serum T4 in the upper range of normal.
    • Thyroid hormone (Option A) should not be administered without glucocorticoid therapy in cases of adrenal insufficiency, as this can lead to an adrenal crisis.
 
  • Sex Hormone Replacement: Recommended for women under 50 years with gonadotropin deficiency and for men to restore sexual function and prevent osteoporosis.
 
  • Growth Hormone Replacement:
    • Growth hormone (GH) is given via daily subcutaneous injections for children and adolescents with GH deficiency (Option D)
    • Side Effects: The primary side effect is sodium retention, which may present as peripheral oedema or carpal tunnel syndrome
    • GH replacement should start at a low dose, with regular monitoring of serum IGF-1 to assess response.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles, galactorrhea, and difficulty conceiving. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum prolactin levels. MRI of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements about the given condition is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Female-to-Male ratio is approximately 20:1 for microadenomas

options.label: B
options.text: Men generally present with symptoms earlier than women

options.label: D
options.text: Prolactin levels correlate with the size of the tumor

questions.correct_answer: B. Men generally present with symptoms earlier than women
questions.explanation:
Causes of galactorrhea

Physiological

Pathological

  • Pregnancy
  • Sleep associated
  • Sexual stimulation
  • Stress
  • Trauma
  • Hypoglycemia
  • High protein diet
  • Prolactinoma
  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
  • Primary hypothyroidism (Increased TRH)
  • Acromegaly (Shared lineage of GH & PRL)
  • Antipsychotic drugs & Dopamine antagonists

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with erectile dysfunction and galactorrhea. Blood tests confirm elevated prolactin levels and an MRI reveals a macroadenoma. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate surgical resection of the tumor

options.label: D
options.text: Start bromocriptine therapy, followed by regular imaging

questions.explanation:
Medical treatment

Dopamine Agonists

First-line treatment option

  • Cabergoline - long action and better tolerance (Option B)
    • Galactorrhea improves in 90% of patients
    • PRL levels are normal in 80% of patients with microadenomas and 70% with macroprolactinomas.
  • Bromocriptine (Option D ruled out)
    • Shorter action - preferable in women wishing to conceive

Side effects may include nausea, mental fogging, nightmares, insomnia, vertigo and postural hypotension

Surgery (Option A ruled out)

Indication

  • Tumor causing pituitary apoplexy
  • Cases resistant to medical therapy
  • Invasive macroadenomas affecting vision
  • Pregnant woman with clinical features of tumor
  • Mass effect of tumor persisting > 1 month with medical therapy

Radiotherapy
  • Reserved for aggressive tumors that do not respond to dopamine agonists or surgery

questions.text: A 32 year old nulliparous woman comes to the OB-GYN department for investigation of infertility. She also complains of occasional headaches and galactorrhoea. Lab tests and imaging lead to a diagnosis of prolactinoma. If we want to restore fertility in this patient, which of the following is the treatment of choice in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Cabergoline therapy till pregnancy is confirmed

options.label: B
options.text: Bromocriptine therapy till pregnancy is confirmed

options.label: C
options.text: Radiotherapy for mass reduction of tumor

questions.correct_answer: B. Bromocriptine therapy till pregnancy is confirmed
questions.explanation:
Treatment of prolactinoma in pregnancy

Desire for fertility

DOC - Bromocriptine

  • Bromocriptine therapy is initiated to restore fertility
  • It is short-acting and has low teratogenic effects
  • Mechanical contraception should be practiced for the first 3 menstrual cycles after initiation of therapy to allow for conception timing
  • After pregnancy is confirmed - the drug is discontinued, and serial monitoring of prolactin levels
  • Drug may be reintroduced if tumor growth is apparent

Visual field defect

If the tumor is very large and threatens the vision, surgical decompression may be done

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the stalk effect of the pituitary?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperprolactinemia occurs due to a hypersecreting macroadenoma

options.label: B
options.text: There is reduced secretion of dopamine in the pituitary stalk

options.label: C
options.text: Significant deficiencies in other pituitary hormones are not present

options.label: D
options.text: Prolactin level is usually less than 200 ng/ml

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyperprolactinemia occurs due to a hypersecreting macroadenoma

questions.text: Match the following pituitary gland disorders with their respective serum hormone levels. Pituitary gland disorder Serum hormone levels 1. Hypopituitarism a) Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones maybe ↓ or normal 2. Sheehan syndrome b) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin, ADH ↓ 3. Pituitary apoplexy c) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH normal or ↓; prolactin ↑ 4. Stalk effect d) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin ↓ and ADH normal
questions.explanation:
Pituitary hormone levels in different pituitary gland disorders

Hypopituitarism

It occurs due to damage in the pituitary gland caused by tumors, surgery, trauma, or genetic conditions.

GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin, ADH ↓ (deficiency varies based on which cells are affected).

Sheehan syndrome

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe blood loss during childbirth.

GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin ↓ and ADH normal

Pituitary apoplexy

A medical emergency involving sudden hemorrhage or infarction in the pituitary gland.

Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones may be ↓ or normal

Stalk effect

Compression or disruption of the pituitary stalk causing a reduction in hypothalamic inhibition of prolactin, resulting in elevated prolactin levels without other pituitary hormone abnormalities.

GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH normal or ↓, prolactin ↑

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of pituitary adenoma presents with sudden-onset severe headache, palpitations, excessive sweating, and hypotension. Lab results show severe hypoglycemia, and imaging reveals hemorrhage within the pituitary and deviation of the pituitary stalk. What is the initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Pituitary apoplexy

Pathology

  • Acute intra-pituitary hemorrhage resulting in an endocrine emergency
  • It may arise spontaneously in preexisting adenomas, occur postpartum or be associated with conditions like diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or acute shock.
  • Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones maybe ↓ or normal

Clinical features

  • Severe headache
  • Central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage
  • Signs of meningeal irritation
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Bilateral visual changes
  • Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis)
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypotension
  • Shock
  • Cardiovascular collapse

Management

  • High-dose glucocorticoids is the first line of treatment to correct adrenal insufficiency, stabilize blood pressure, and correct hypoglycemia.
  • Patients without evident visual loss or impaired consciousness can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids.
  • Urgent surgical decompression: Required for patients with significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness.
  • Monitoring: Visual recovery is inversely correlated with the duration of time after the acute event, so timely intervention is crucial.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is mismatched with its hormonal profile and management

options.label: A
options.text: Lymphocytic hypophysitis - variable deficiency in pituitary hormone Sheehan syndrome - treated with hormone replacement therapy Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - ADH deficiency present

options.label: B
options.text: Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Glucocorticoid to reduce inflammation Sheehan syndrome - Panhypopituitarism Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - surgical excision of the lesion

options.label: C
options.text: Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Glucocorticoid to reduce inflammation Sheehan syndrome - ADH deficiency present Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary-thyroid hormone replacement is essential.

options.label: D
options.text: Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Surgical excision if vision is affected Sheehan syndrome - Thyroid hormone replacement after Corticosteroids are stabilized Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - Chemotherapy is systemic involvement present

questions.correct_answer: C. Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Glucocorticoid to reduce inflammation Sheehan syndrome - ADH deficiency present Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary-thyroid hormone replacement is essential.
questions.explanation:
Features

Sheehan syndrome

Lymphocytic hypophysitis

LCH of pituitary

Cause

Occurs due to postpartum ischemic necrosis of the pituitary, commonly presenting with panhypopituitarism

An autoimmune inflammation of the pituitary, causing variable hormone deficiencies

Infiltration of the pituitary by Langerhans cells

Hormone profile

Panhypopituitarism, except for ADH

Variable deficiencies: often low ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, PRL,

ADH deficiency presenting as central diabetes insipidus

 

May have low or normal pituitary hormones depending on the degree of infiltration

Treatment

Hormone replacement

  • Glucocorticoid replacement to manage adrenal insufficiency.
  • Thyroid hormone replacement after corticosteroids are stabilized.
  • Gonadal hormone replacement

Corticosteroids to manage inflammation

 

Hormone replacement as needed for any deficiencies.

 

Surgery only if visual field compromise or other complications arise.

Surgical resection of affected mass

 

Chemotherapy may be needed if systemic involvement present

  • Vinblastine
  • Methotrexate-containing regimens
  • Cytarabine

questions.text: Which of the following is the sequence of hormonal supplementation in a patient of Panhypopituitarism

options.label: A
options.text: Glucocorticoids → Thyroid hormones → Growth hormone → Sex hormones

options.label: B
options.text: Glucocorticoid → thyroid hormone → Sex hormones → Growth hormone

options.label: C
options.text: Thyroid hormones → Sex hormones → Glucocorticoids → Growth hormone

options.label: D
options.text: Sex hormones → Growth hormone → Glucocorticoids → Thyroid hormones

questions.correct_answer: B. Glucocorticoid → thyroid hormone → Sex hormones → Growth hormone
questions.explanation:
Hormonal therapy for Panhypopituitarism

Hormone deficient

Hormone replacement

ACTH

Corticosteroid replacement should be started first to reduce the risk of triggering an adrenal crisis.

  • Hydrocortisone 10-20 mg/day in divided doses
  • Cortisone acetate 15-25 mg/day in divided doses
  • Prednisolone 5 mg/day

TSH

Thyroid hormone replacement is then added for hypothyroidism

  • L-thyroxine 0.0075 - 0.15 mg/day

FSH/LH

After thyroid hormone replacement - sex hormone replacement is initiated

  • Males - testosterone
  • Females - estrogen / progesterone / gonadotropins

GH
  • Adults - Somatotropin (0.1 - 1.25 mg SC QID)
  • Children - Somatotropin (0.02 - 0.05 mg/kg/day)

Vasopressin

  • Intranasal desmopressin (5–20 g BID/day)
  • Oral 300–600 μg QID
